text: Saudi Arabia is an immensely
conservative country why because it's
people are very conservative and the
people would often imagine I think that
the rulers are holding it back in terms
of reforms actually it's quite the
opposite
King Abdullah despite his advanced years
was a reformer and he pushed quite hard
for the role of women the pushback
against that was the religious
conservatives who don't want to see them
driving who don't want to see them have
any kind of public or political role now
the focus will be on King Salman disease
his father and whether he will continue
those reforms I personally think is
unlikely he's fairly conserved himself
he was governor Riyadh a very important
post for quite some time he's been crown
prince and defense minister very
important roles so the the priority of
Assad is now is going to be stability
continuing the way for as far as the Al
Saud the ruling time here and the
religious conservatives concerned they
will want to resist any kind of violent
change that they've seen in the
so-called Arab Spring Saudi Arabia is
one of those countries that managed to
resist the Arab Spring which is it
surprised a lot of people because it's
probably the least democratic country in
the entire Middle East and yet with the
combination of billions of dollars of
tight security of allegiance to the
ruling family and particularly to King
Abdullah Saudi Arabia was able to and
also a number of arrests they were able
to resist the Arab Spring they don't
like it they issued a fat rather well
they got the the religious rule America
the religious clerics do issue a fatwa
against any demonstrations public in
favor of the Arab Spring clamping down
on a protest and I think that Saudi
Arabia will probably continue in this
vein they fear dramatic change they
don't like dramatic change King Salman
as he now is is obviously was expecting
to take on this role he was somebody who
was very closely involved inside a
Raiders role against the Syrian regime
the Saudis were appalled that America
didn't carry out airstrikes against
Bashar Assad's regime following the gas
attacks in the autumn of 2013 he flew
back from his holiday in Morocco ready
to take control of Saudi Arabia's
defences expecting to play a military
role in any kind of US offensive against
the Syrian regime instead of which of
course as we know there was a deal to
eliminate Syria's chemical weapons and
there were no air strikes against
Syria's regime instead of which they now
find themselves in extraordinary
position of being a part of the
coalition the the us-led coalition
against Islamic state this is a very
difficult time societies because many
Saudis do not understand why their
country is supporting infidel America as
some would call it against their fellow
brethren in Syria and and Iraq and they
oppose those airstrikes so Saudi Arabia
is going to have I think an increasing
internal security problem
